+Thomas Jefferson It's pronounced exactly as it sounds, "Yeh-shoe-uh" so to 
break it down it would be a "y" then an "eh sound like when you say forever 
(for"eh"ver), then the shu is pronounced as "shoe" like the footwear, and 
then the a at the end is a short "uh" sound. The y at the beginning does 
tend to have a very subtle "J" tone to it, which is why it was changed to 
Jesus later on which was the latin translation of the name, as jews have a 
lack of vowels in the alefbet as well as no dedicated "J" which was 
replaced with Y (this is similar to how many asians, most famously 
japanese, have trouble pronouncing the letter L, because there is no L in 
the japanese kana, it is replaced with the letter R which when spoken in 
words sounds very similar. So you get names like Takurou (T-ah-koo-row) 
where the R at the end sounds like an L when pronounced in japanese, as if 
they are saying "Takulou") Note that the naming of Jesus as Yeshua is also 
significant as it's a name quite close to god, who's name was Yahweh; the 
true name of god which is never spoken by jews; it is made up of four 
letters, Yod hey vav hey (Y H V H, which is sounded out as Y + H = yah , V 
+ H = weh, since there is no W letter, V replaces it, so we have V + H 
being equal to W + H, and since there are no vowels, the E in the middle of 
WEH isn't there, only used when speaking) Jesus was also given the name 
Emmanuel at his birth, which means "god is with us" and is also part of the 
prophecy Isaiah gave, saying that the messiah would have the name Emmanuel.
